thread.title: Brexit bill protest on Quayside LIVE: Updates as pro-Europe campaign gathers in Gateshead
thread.title_full: Brexit bill protest on Quayside LIVE: Updates as pro-Europe campaign gathers in Gateshead

author: Kathryn Riddell
title: Brexit bill protest on Quayside LIVE: Updates as pro-Europe campaign gathers in Gateshead
text:
Protesters show support for EU 
More demonstrators are now arriving. 
Bridget Gubbins has travelled down from Morpeth for today’s protest. Bridget Gubbins at the North East for Europe protest (Photo: Chris Knight) 11:58 Kathryn Riddell Protest getting under way on Quayside 
Reporter Chris Knight has arrived at Gateshead Quayside where the protest is due to be held. 
An EU flag has already been unfurled. 11:41 KEY EVENT When will Brexit negotiations begin? 
The Prime Minister looks set to wait another fortnight before kicking off the two-year process of negotiating departure under Article 50 of the EU treaties, with formal notification expected to take place in the last week of March. Theresa May (Photo: PA) 
Mrs May’s official spokesman played down suggestions that the PM had delayed notification due to Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon’s announcement that she plans to stage a second independence referendum in the run-up to the expected date of Brexit in spring 2019. 
There was widespread speculation in Westminster that she could do so as early as today, when she is scheduled to make a statement on Europe to the Commons. 11:36 Kathryn Riddell Brexit to go ahead 
Once the Bill receives Royal Assent it becomes an Act of Parliament and the Prime Minister has all the authority she needs to trigger Article 50 at the time of her choosing. 11:25 KEY EVENT Prime Minister set to trigger Article 50 
The Prime Minister is now fully in control of the process after the House of Commons voted to give her the power to trigger Article 50 without any conditions or restrictions. Theresa May, who was given a fresh warning about the difficulties she will face in Brexit negotiations with Europe as peers prepared for battle with ministers over the Article 50 Bill (Photo: PA) 
It means negotiations about a new trade deal with the EU, which may last two years, can begin by April. 
The House of Lords had attempted to amend the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill, which allows Brexit to go ahead. 
One amendment required the Government to give Parliament a “meaningful vote” on a Brexit deal once it is finally agreed by the UK government and the rest of the EU, while a second amendment requiring the Government to confirm that citizens of other EU countries who are currently in the UK legally will be allowed to stay. 
But the House of Commons rejected the Lords proposals, after Ministers said that tying the Government’s hands would make it harder to get a good deal out of the EU. 11:13 Kathryn Riddell Bill amendments rejected 
After weeks of bitter wrangling in both Houses, the Government comfortably fought off two Liberal Democrat bids to again amend the Brexit Bill in the Lords. 
In a day of drama, the Commons voted to reject two changes made by peers to the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill, which gives the Prime Minister the power to trigger the two-year Brexit talks. 
MPs voted against a proposal to unilaterally guarantee the rights of EU nationals living in the UK within three months, by 335 votes to 287, majority 48. 11:05 Kathryn Riddell Brexit bill protest on the Quayside 
A pro-Europe group will hold a demonstration at Gateshead Quayside after the Brexit bill took a step closer to being passed. 
The North East for Europe campaign will meet at the Millennium Bridge on Tuesday afternoon displaying EU flags and placards. 
They say the event is intended to “demonstrate opposition to Parliament’s passing of the Brexit Bill and its the failure to ensure a meaningful vote on the EU exit deal”. 
The group go on to say that they are concerned about the Government’s failure to safeguard the position of EU citizens living and working in the North East. 
We’ll have live updates from the protest this afternoon from our reporter Chris Knight. Share
